Description: Tondo sherd of Attic black-figured pottery late Siana cup or early little master cup; interior: part of band of alternating red and black tongues outside three bands; in tondo, part of female head to right; face drawn in outline strengthened with incision; curlicue rising from top of head, dotted diadem, red on alternating, incised, locks of hair; exterior glazed.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The curlicue is reminiscent of those found on sphinxes' heads in Chian Archaic pottery.
For female figures painted in outline compare the work of the Amasis Painter as well as several Little Master cup painters; the feature is rare inside tondos, however.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0405) (Phase 1)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 62, pl. VIII, no. 8)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
